title: Marks & Spencer CFO to Depart Amid Cost-Saving Effort at U.K. Retailer
text:
Britain’s Marks & Spencer Group PLC is searching for a new finance chief to help it find cost savings.

The London-based retailer said Saturday that Chief Financial Officer Humphrey Singer will depart after just over a year in the role, a move that comes in the middle of a turnaround effort.

M&S said Mr. Singer will remain in his position until a departure date has been decided and that a search for a successor is under way.

“After eighteen months of working with [Chief Executive Steve Rowe ] to lead the transformation strategy and rebuild the finance function I have decided that now is the right time to move on,” Mr. Singer said, according to a release.

“One of the problems [at M&S] is that people who were brought in for the transformation are leaving before it is halfway through,” said Adam Cochrane, an analyst at Citigroup Inc. Before the exit of its finance chief, M&S saw other top executives leave, including the head of its clothing business, Jill McDonald.

The company is looking to find £350 million ($436.3 million) in cumulative savings by fiscal 2020-21 through a mix of store closures, technology improvements and organizational changes. Around £100 million of that already has been achieved, the retailer said in its most recent annual report.

M&S has been struggling with volatile sales in its food and clothing business while facing industrywide challenges such as rising commercial property taxes and Britain’s coming departure from the European Union, which could result in distortions to supply chains, analysts said.

A new finance chief succeeding Mr. Singer is expected to advance the cost-reduction efforts, analysts said. “Delivering on the cost-savings plan is currently the single biggest role for the finance director,” said Mr. Cochrane, adding that there would be little room for a new CFO to make significant changes to the current strategy.

The company plans to close stores while also reducing the number of employees in the head office. Outsourcing certain information technology functions is set to bring additional efficiencies, according to Mr. Cochrane.

The new CFO is likely also going to be involved with managing the financial implications of a deal that M&S struck with online food retailer Ocado Group PLC earlier this year. As part of the transaction, M&S got a 50% stake in Ocado’s U.K. food delivery arm to boost its online offering.

Cost and revenue synergies are expected, analysts said, and M&S will have the chance to purchase the remaining part of the business in a few years.

M&S financed a large part of the transaction with a rights issue. Its share price has declined around 20% since the beginning of the year, resulting in an exclusion from the FTSE 100 index of biggest companies in Britain that took effect Monday.

Managing the financial consequences of Brexit, currently scheduled for Oct. 23, also could be among the tasks for a new CFO, analysts said. M&S sources part of its fresh produce from Continental Europe and a chaotic Brexit without a separation agreement between the U.K. and the EU could upend those supply chains, according to Eleonora Dani, an analyst at investment bank Stifel Nicolaus Europe Ltd.

M&S didn’t immediately respond to a request for additional comment.

Write to Nina Trentmann at nina.trentmann@wsj.com
description: The finance chief of British retailer Marks & Spencer is leaving after just over a year in the role, a move that comes in the middle of a turnaround effort.
